LOOK THE FIRST & ONLY AD EVER ON BLUEHAT!

It's probably because Eli started his own affiliate network

Blue Hat SEO-Advanced SEO Tactics

New To Blue Hat SEO?
  Here are a few posts the other readers recommend you check out.
  • SEO Empire - Part 1
  • Blue Hat Technique #19 - Keyword Spinning
  • SERP Domination
  • Captchas Captchas Captchas
  • QUIT- Quick Indexing Tool
User Contributed12 Jul 2010 02:14 pm

Open Questions: When To Never Do Article Submissions

Got a question in my E-Commerce SEO Checklist post from Rania, who didn’t leave me a link for credit.

“4. Steal your competitors articles and product reviews and do article distribution.”

You recommend STEALING articles from competitors as an advanced SEO tactic?! Seriously?!

How about recommending that users create their own unique content in order to increase their site traffic and ranking.

Suggesting that people steal competitors work really says a lot about you- and your company.

Good luck.

I know you’re only trying to make a point but I’ll accept the question anyway.

Why would I steal my competitors articles for article distribution instead of writing/sharing my own?

The answer is much more than a time or ethics response.

1. Unnecessary Competition
A typical article distribution involves submitting to around 1-5k worth of article directories and E-zines. Any time you submit the same piece of content to that many sites it creates unnecessary competition. This is especially true if your site is new. The article directories and ezines are old, your site is new. They win. While they usually won’t take you out on the primary keywords especially with your site linked in the article, they can snag a lot of unknown positions in your longtail and mediumtailed phrases pushing your site down and losing you an unknown bit of long term traffic. This can go all the way up to a worse case scenario. Last year when Acai Berry was a hot niche a lot of people were seoing for the term and many did article distributions. While their sites never made it into the top 10, the articles they submitted came closer. So when Google did some manual reviews and bitch slapped a bunch of rebill promoters and affiliate pages on the term most of what was left was the articles. All ranking and for awhile there while everyone else readjusted left a bunch of article directories taking all that good traffic. The first thing the article directory owners did of course was edit the articles and take out the links to the authors websites and throw in their own affiliate links. Lesson learned, but that brings us to point two.

2. Don’t Do It Unless Others Are
ESPECIALLY IF YOU ARE IN A SMALL NICHE! God damn, I see people do this all the time. They find a nice little niche with nearly zero competition and in the miniscule effort they have to put into ranking they realize the only way they know how to build backlinks is to article submit. They get flooded out and cry. Uhhg. The point is, same as point one. Don’t do it unless others are. I follow the rule outlined in SEO Empire, if you want to win Match and Exceed. If it becomes a problem for you to maintain your ranking, then submit where they submit and a bit more. So don’t submit unless you have to, but if you do make sure you…

3. Submit Your Competitors Articles Only
All those same articles on thousands of sites creates a massive duplicate content penalty opportunity. So the worst choice you can make is to go through the articles published on your site and submit them. In the middle of the bad choices spectrum would be to write unique articles and submit those. Unique articles are for pulling in seo traffic and thus they belong on your site and preferably nowhere else. You throw little fits when people steal your content, why would you willingly give it out? The wisest choice is to submit your competitors articles because if you’re going to put anyone at risk for duplicate content you might as well put them not yourself. I’ve always said, there’s two ways to rank: You going up or them going down. I own about 170 article directories as part of my basement. I understand how the article game is played. People aren’t submitting articles to my sites because they want my directory to be the best smelling turd around. They want the links. I want the pages of content for link laundering and they want the links, that is what its all about and nothing more. No one owes me unique articles, nor is it doing them any favors to give them to me.

Hope that clears up the game rules for you Rania, sorry its not advanced, but there’s good reasons for everything we do. Please understand, I don’t tell people to be evil just because I enjoy watching them be evil (even though I do). There is always some form of risk whenever you are. Yet never hesitate to be evil when its a sink or swim situation, always match and exceed.

Comment by SEO steve

Yeah, and there is a fairly large problem with strategies like ” Submit Your Competitors Articles” Aside from being black-hat, the domain owner could be sued for copyright infringement. You might have it set to private, but that doesn’t protect you from the law.

If you’re in a competitive industry or one that is centered online, this is not a good idea.

Comment by alex
- 2010-07-13 00:59:34

“How about recommending that users create their own unique content” – spin

“… in order to increase their site traffic” - A little bit off-topic, but not sure if Rania is aware of this retarded trick.

Register a domain, create a blog and post a few articles (steal). Then ask your writer(s) to create a sales copy with a link to your blog. Anchor text smth like ‘Click here…’ or ‘Read more…’ is Ok. Submit the article to ezine (or another trusted domain). Spam. Your goal is #10.

If #10 achieved, then you have two options. White-hat lazy-ass marketer’s way - develop your blog and wait until someone clicks the link in the article, visit your blog and buy smth, i.e. article – blog – commission. Or, white-hat lazy-ass marketer’s way #2 . Redirect your blog to affiliate link. You skip the ‘- blog -’ part. Obviously, article will be deleted one day.

Is it “ok” for NFL QBs to consistently rape women, not get sentenced to jail and still make Million$ a year?

And you’re hear on BHS wasting valuable comment space talking about a silly article?

If the public world does not care about Big illegal things why would anyone give a second thought to a simple article?

Grow a pair and keep reading or go read the Sesame Street SEO blog on the next corner.

Mike

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Joseph
- 2010-08-01 00:47:52

To all who don’t understand this post. What happens is that you spend time and writing a 100% unique article and submit to a site. Your competitors will steal and spin it and resubmit it on the same site with their links, making your article’s value drop. So why do it?

Put the unique article on your own website or some place else. Doesn’t mean that a competitor won’t steal it also. Happens to me all the time.

His point is that if you are going to put an article out there why make it unique, it will get duplicated 100x within a year.

Comment by Jump Media Design
- 2010-08-11 07:18:18

There’s nothing that creates more of a response than something of controversy. I can see your point of view with regards to article submission. Writing content has become more challenging now than ever before with the flood of articles and other content across the Internet.

I’ll spend hours writing ‘unique articles’ and after submission notified that content looks like duplicate. Leverage is the key these days. I guess that’s what blue hat SEO is – Not All white, and definitely Black Hat. Is it?

It’s pretty much what they teach you these days: Do what your competitors do but much better. Learn from their mistakes -capitalise on in and build on their strongpoint - Be the Best –not just better.

Comment by Synth
- 2010-08-12 02:41:57

Lo and behold I was just trawling the serps and I found someone’s site totally outranked by their own ezine articles for their prime keywords. Not only that, but they are spending their time building someone else’s real estate! Congratulating yourself on your ezine article is like congratulating yourself on the $10 you put in the bank, all the while oblivious that the guy owning the bank is the real winner, they have thousands of people effectively working for them, building their asset power which they then use to put an even bigger gap between them and you, all the while they offer little parcels of opportunity that help you a bit but help them even more. Asset control seems like its just as much a business axiom online as offline.
There are plenty of ways to score links on authority domains without having to donate a page of content to their cause.

Comment by Digital Gupshup

Reply to this comment
Comment by Internet Marketing For Newbies
- 2010-08-25 12:52:42

It is actually not true. You do not get any duplicate content penalty for submitting an article that is published on your website to article directories. Some may not publish it since it is not unique, but that’s the worst that will happen. Duplicate content penalties only come into play when you post the same thing on your website multiple times. When you submit a single article to multiple directories, that is called syndication and you do not get any penalties for that. Google will not let you go hurt your competition by simply distributing their articles to as many article directories as possible. If you leave their link in the article, you’re just doing them a favor. And to claim their article as your own is breaking copyright laws. There are some harsh penalties if your competition really takes it personally and does something about it.

Reply to this comment
 
 
Comment by Hampton Window Cleaning
- 2010-08-22 03:34:08

Interesting information a lot of truth in what you are saying.

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by portable hard drive
- 2010-08-22 22:11:56

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Escort Service London
- 2010-08-23 08:40:58

One must have a unique content before submitting to thousands of free articles out there that have even set to dofollow on their links attributes.

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Donald Lewleyn
- 2010-08-23 09:11:13

The fact that Google will rank a page about whatever topic from EzineArticles highly is one thing but why do you believe that the links from the article submission pages back to your site are followed/valued by Google, they were obviously submitted by the site owner, why on earth would Google count such a link, wether it is nofollow or dofollow is irrelevant.

By creating these articles, be they original, spun or copied you are just increasing the page count of another site - which merrily adds it’s own advertising, you make nothing and get no link value - article marketing is a fools errand.

You can write the most wonderful article, submit it to Ezine, watch it rank and get zero link benefit - unless of course people actually click on the link, in terms of linkvalue it is a waste of time.

Also if you submit an original article to a article site it will generally rank, but additional submissions of the same article seldom rank, it is a waste of time, the same is true of spun articles in my experience.

Your ideas sound fine until they are read through and examined, they then sound very amateurish.

Reply to this comment

Comment by Web Design Chester
- 2010-10-03 17:55:53

I think your site offers a variety of useful information but stealing competitors articles is a little risky. As soon as private companies find a way of proving ownership, the potential profits from suing individuals for copyright infringements would be huge. The old trick of sending yourself a parcel, through the post, with your content in is available online. Secure server deposits where the item can not be modified (not even by the moderators) are available. Whether this could prove ownership I don’t know but is something to be aware of.

Comment by SearchTrax

i don’t think its that simple.. when ever we get a new website in a new field we first must learn it..

that takes a while.. i first start by reading competitors articles while i rewrite them in my words. that way i learn about the subject while building links.

my seo company offers a content creation service inside the seo package.. so you see…?

when i feel our staff is in control of the material, then and only then would we create new pages inside the clients website cuz’ we want to make them
long, high quality pages and not seen like fools..

does that sound logical ?

Comment by alex
- 2010-10-24 09:54:13

I would like to report a flaw detected in IE.
Saying thank you in any post is redirected to the technical page (with the text “You thank the author of the message”), after which it will return to the page topic. Error occurs if the IE after redirect to the page topic click “Back” button: the browser will attempt to reload the page, but the poor script will complain to “Duplicate entry”.
The same can be done rebooting technical page standard web browser

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by tessel
- 2011-01-02 23:57:21

Eli,
I found your site sometime ago and thoroughly enjoyed the SEO Empire Part I post. However, speaking honestly it has taken some time for it to sink in and get a better understanding of what you were saying. I realize that was 3 years ago now and I’ve a few questions.

1) How broad a topic for the foundation sites would you recommend?

How generic or how specific should the site be? If it is too general, then I am wondering if that would be a problem, but if the site’s topic was TOO specific, I am not sure how possible it would be to get so many pages indexed/content created easily. I guess an example would be a foundation site on the topic COMPUTER versus a foundation site on the topic COMPUTER GAMES. I think the COMPUTER GAMES would be better because the content would be more specific which would help drive up a money page if I created one based or related to computer games in someway.

2) What’s the best way to make “content”?

Obviously there’s no easy answer to this question, and if there is I doubt, and don’t blame, people for not wanting to share. I see you recommended database driven sites, but the content appeared to be very “static”. I am not sure if that has changed in the 3 years since you made that post. I am wondering if it is best to buy PLR and just spin the content. Obviously this could turn out to be very time consuming, but I am not sure how else you could get semi useful content that doesn’t look like you’ve chopped it up with an online translating program that spits out useless garbage.

Either way I want to say a huge thanks. One of the biggest stumbling blocks I’ve noticed is that launching a site is easy, it is actually getting the links to it. The thought of making a landing page and then building up the link sites or web 2.0 sites for that specific topic EVERY TIME I make a new money site seems a huge waste of time. I am not saying this shouldn’t be done, but you’ve answered a nagging question in my brain which was HOW can I get semi relevant or at least an injection of links to help push up a new site and then work on get relevant/more specific links etc. I think the only way to answer my question is to TRY, and build up what I consider to be a foundation site. Thought I’d see if you had any other tips before I start. If not, no problem. I have enjoyed reading your stie and will continue reading. Happy New Year.

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Michael
- 2011-01-04 19:44:29

First, thanks for the excellent posts. I found your site several years ago, but it’s taken all this time for things to even start to make sense. I am a long way from really “knowing” the ins and outs of everything you’ve posted here, so I have a few questions to ask.

1) Foundation sites - Still effective?

I think this is something I do finally get. There’s many sites that “somehow” have 40k back links, and while I am sure many of them are legit, it makes sense that they use networks to get these links. Since the original post was in 2007, I am curious if you’ve had to make any “changes” to your sites, or have you seen them losing “link power”? Getting a network of sites is something I see as a must. The links may not all be high PR or from unique IPs, but I can see how useful they are. One thing that turns me off from launching a new website, regardless of how small the niche/competition is, is that the amount of work required to get links. You called it “building from the top down”, and it’s the reason why I think network sites are great. Have you see the “power” of these foundation sites drop over the years?

2) Building foundation sites and their “market”

This question relates to the first. What’s the best way for someone who currently lacks the knowledge to use databases and SQL to build one and how market specific should they be for best results? I’ve had my best success building web 2.0 sites with spun content (unique article I write that I spin several times for multiple platforms), but the problem again is that this is a lot of work. I’ve nothing against working hard, but if you launch ten sites, it means building from the “top down” 10 times over. I want to make my life easier in the long run, not harder.

I guess the only thing I should do is just try, but thought I’d ask anyway. My current way of launching a new site is how I believe 99% of others do it. Build the money page, then build up the supporting network specific to that landing page niche (profile links, articles and web 2.0). It works, but its short-term and very niche specific. Your notion of “real estate” is what finally clicked with me. I am just trying to make sure that the time required I spend building my real estate is at least half right.

Reply to this comment

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Jenn@t1 service
- 2011-01-10 14:26:03

Okay, there are a few problems with this technique. First, stealing other people’s articles is a violation of copyright law. It’s a good way to get yourself in trouble.

Second, Matt Cutts at Google says there is no such thing as a duplicate content penalty. Duplicate content just gets filtered out of the search results. In all cases they try to just show the original source.

Third, Google has stated that it tries to keep algorithms free of loopholes competitors can exploit to tank other people’s rankings. So you can’t actually tank somebody’s rankings or give them a duplicate content penalty (which doesn’t exist) by doing this!

Reply to this comment

- 2011-01-10 22:58:17

Comment by Bruce Dog
- 2011-03-24 23:31:50

Amongst all the spam comments … I am going to ask a real question. Being a dog walker and coming from Australia. I have a niche and maybe because of the .au site suffix, no direct competition with the article sites? That is, hoping the US article sites send traffic, and my own site in Aus ranks high enough in Google (when people just search for Aus sites) to rate higher than the article sites.

On other client sites I have submitted 100% original articles that are on their sites to the article sites, without spinning. DO YOU KNOW if there is a penalty for this duplicate content for this fairly low number of site submissions?

To get around this, is it worth spinning articles, or only posting half the original article on the article sites?

Besides blog commenting like on your site, article site submission is still listed by most seo guru sources as the way to go … what else is there???

Thanks!

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Michael B
- 2011-03-26 03:48:01

I am probably a bit old-fashioned. I always write my own articles and write the things I believe is important to write about. Now, I might not get the best amount of visitors this way, but it feels good to be able to 100% know that I wrote it and I believe it is rewarding over time.

It also feels that this is something that can be given penalty for, as Bruce writes in his question. It might not be now, but it might over time.

This way of thinking has helped me quite a lot. I am no 1 on some good words on Google and jumped from 55th to 15th place on another really important word after Google changed the algorithm recently.

It is important to understand that my site is only a few months old as well.

Reply to this comment
Comment by Bruce Dog
- 2011-03-26 19:16:57

Hi Michael,

My site is very new too. And I write all of my own articles, but because I either research expert articles on other sites (providing reference to them), or analyse Google data and create reports on a specific industry. I do this rather than just claiming my musings as a 500 word ‘article’. This means my articles often take days to perfect, rather than one or two hours, like some OS churn factories.

While I appreciate that this is doing the ‘right thing’ the length of time I take to make the article means that competitors can put up ten non-sense articles in the same time. Funnily enough I have found my emotive articles (easy to write), such as when discussing diseases related to gluten free are published, they score many more reads that pure research and state of the market articles. I appreciate the ‘give the people what they want’ theory, but it just may be that article site cruisers are just looking for a ‘good read’ or to pillage your article, where as the wider google search community may appreciate original research and trend reporting more? This seems to be the case when i check analytics.

Frustrating that it is, I am just looking at a way of not dumbing down my articles, and still be able to leverage them (maybe that does mean spinning them)?

As a by the way, i submit the articles to get people interested in the full story to visit my site and maybe provide one way links if they like what they find. the article sites are not about raw visitor numbers.

Reply to this comment

Article submission have never been a part of my linking strategy because i don’t like thinking up and writing up an article only to have it rank higher for the keywords than my site. Since i can use the competitors articles, that has now stopped my excuses lol.

Comment by Frank Zhou

Music Fountain，Musical Fountain, Water Fountain
Music fountain control states of water and lamps with musical characteristic. A good musical fountain is a wonderful artwork, which may make our environment more beautiful and joyful. And its control system is the key technique.
Musical fountain is a type of animated fountain for entertainment purposes that creates an aesthetic design and sometimes a three-dimensional image. This is done by using the effects of sound waves and light or laser against water particles, in which the water streams, activated in strategically-timed durations, refract and reflect the light, and in doing so, a three-dimensional image is created.

Changsha Himalaya Music Fountain Corporation Limited

Comment by SEO Victoria

Just to help out Laminat, I have found that article submission works for SEO. To be honest, I still do it, even after the Panda nuke. It depends on the niche of course though. With that said, if you don’t like writing, then don’t bother. It will show.

Comment by tv vanavond
- 2011-09-29 03:07:39

When you submit a single article to multiple directories, that is called syndication and you do not get any penalties for that. Google will not let you go hurt your competition by simply distributing their articles to as many article directories as possible.

Comment by Loc

So get one that that can fool the search engine but readable to the human eye.

Comment by Korting
- 2012-01-04 10:01:42

Although I think that you defended yourself quite well, I still tend to agree with rania. “Stealing” your competitor’s content is never acceptable. If you want to make money with your website or generate traffic, then the only ethic way is to make sure that your website actually stands out. Standing out doesn’t mean copying, it means creating something unique. How can copying something be unique? To answer my own question: it can’t be. Too all bloggers, webmasters, please create your own content and refrain from copying. It might take you a bit longer to achieve what you want, but you’ll get there.

Comment by Sam Roberts
- 2012-03-24 14:18:31

Very interesting perspective. Submitting site content to article directories is a real trade-off. It brings your site some link juice, but can ultimately affect your own long-tail rankings. Something to always keep in mind.

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Tom
- 2012-06-21 01:38:23

While I can kinda agree with what you’re saying, if you literally rip off your competitor’s content and they come after you (perhaps forcing you to remove or change content) then you’re screwed. All your juice and backlinks from the article directories are gone.

The key thing to do is, while there are some directories that do strip external links at will, is to find the best directories that are more fair with their article moderation and stick to them. Become established on the better websites.

And if you have to change stolen content for an article submission, you might as well take your time to write something original yourself. Other articles should be used for inspiration or for an idea on a popular topic. With most article directories having a minimum of 350-400 words, it doesn’t take too long to write an original piece of work.

Reply to this comment

Traces of many civilizations on the Pendik, is located in the fishing village of the Ottoman period. Later destroyed in a fire in its current Pendik, re-projected by the Lord Chief Azaryan has become the center of a city. Previously, Üsküdar and then connects to the town of Gebze in Pendik, on the Republic of Turkey, in 1987, gained the title of the district. 9 km north of the Marmara Sea coastline adjacent to the campus, Gebze, Çekmeköy, Sancaktepe, Eagle and neighboring municipalities are Sultanbeyli. The district has a total of 36 quarters of Istanbul, which is the largest source of drinking water, which also owns Omerli Dam district.

Reply to this comment
 
Comment by Başakşehir evden eve nakliyat
- 2012-08-23 23:20:35

başakşehir istanbulun avrupa yakasında denize kıyısı olmayan bir ilçesidir. ilçenin kurulduğu bölgenin tarihi oldukça eskidir. ilçeye üniversite açılması planlanmaktadır. ilçenin güneyinden tem otoyolu geçtiği gibi demiryolları da başakşehirden geçmektedir. türkiyenin en büyük yapay göleti olan bahçeşehirdeki gölette ilçededir. ayrıca türkiyenin en büyük stadyumu atatürk olimpiyat stadı da bu ilçededir. yerleşim yerleri sosyo kültürel ve doğal zenginlikleriyle başakşehir istanbulun önemli ilçelerinden biridir. nakliye sektörü için de önemli yere sahip olan başakşehirin taşımacılıkla ilgili tüm ihtiyaçlarını profesyonellerin tercihi olan akdeniz nakliyat olarak karşılamak için hizmet vermekteyiz.

we have PowerMta Video tutorial in this we cover these topics

The topics which we covered in this video tutorial
• Introduction of Power MTA
• Installing PowerMTA
• License Activation
• Installing and configuring DNS
• Features of PowerMTA
• Configuring Virtual-MTA
• Max-message-rate
• Max-message-per-connection
• Define bounce after
• Define Retry Domain on particular time period
• Giving access on web for monitoring purpose
• Define HTTP management Port
• Configure SMTP username and password
• Configure SMTP port
• Increase PowerMTA queues
• Reload PowerMTA configuration file
• How to debug PowerMTA
• Generate SPF and DKIM
• Publish SPF and DKIM on DNS
• Define DKIM on PowerMTA
• How to connect Interspire applications or other application
• Start, Pause and delete queue on PowerMTA
• Delete particular queue on PowerMTA
• Checking powerMTA log
• How to check IP and Domain blacklist
• Delist your IP And domain

I must agree that article submission sites at this point in time are worthless. Still, we publish about an article a week on few of these sites. Most of these articles get picked up by many other sites which can provide us with valuable link backs.

We have been following this approach for the last couple of months. It helped push our ranking for some of the key words we were competing for.

Reply to this comment
